awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Promoting Chemical Biology Education and Research: Understanding Molecular Recognition in Membranes
awd_abstract_narration: This award in the Chemistry of Life Processes program of the Chemistry Division is co-funded by the Biomolecular Systems Cluster in the Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences. The award supports work by Dr. Hang (Hubert) Yin at the University of Colorado at Boulder to carry out fundamental studies on understanding the molecular recognition in cellular membranes and to establish a solid foundation for an integrative chemical biology educational program in the Front Range region. Integral membrane proteins regulate pivotal biological processes through their transmembrane domains. But molecular recognition in the cellular membrane is little understood due to the lack of available probes with high affinity and specificity. Dr. Yin's group aims to develop a generally applicable method to probe molecular recognition in representative membrane protein systems (e.g. Escherichia coli aspartate receptor, Tar). The pedagogic activities involve establishing an infrastructure for a progressive, integrative chemical biology program that empowers diverse groups of students, researchers and educators. Collaboration with local high schools will be carried out, promoting chemical biology and biotechnology interest in the youth. Another major focus of our integrative research and education program is on promoting under-represented minority groups in science within the Boulder population. This work will positively impact scientific advancements and the local community by: (1) expanding the fundamental understanding of molecular recognition in cellular membranes; (2) shedding light on the poorly understood mechanisms of signal transduction across membranes, and (3) integrating research, teaching, and outreach activities at the University of Colorado at Boulder.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF COLORADO

por.por_cntn:
Protein recognition and interaction at the transmembrane domains of integral membrane proteins regulate many pivotal biological processes in the cell. But molecular recognition in the cellular membrane is poorly understood due to the lack of available probes with high affinity and specificity. Our objective is to develop a generally applicable method to study the protein association of previously inaccessible integral membrane proteins. These studies demonstrated a new strategy to identify peptide and small molecule disruptors for investigating transmembrane protein-protein interactions. Further,  with our computational and experimental platforms established for investigating membrane protein-protein interactions, we recently started applying these methods to study the even less understood protein-lipid interactions. In particular, we focused on membrane curvature and lipid composition recognition.

With the NSF CAREER award, we have been aiming to establish an active chemical biology program at CU-Boulder to attract top chemistry, biology and engineering students; to train the next generation of researchers for basic research and biotech/pharmaceutical industries; and to develop a dynamic research group vertically integrated with post-doctoral, graduate, undergraduate, and high-school students from diverse backgrounds. We ave successfully developed an interdisciplinary chemical biology course, CHEM 5341: Chemical Biology and Drug Discovery, which serves to educate and train students on the fundamental basics of chemical methods in biological systems. Finally, we have been actively engaging in a variety of outreach educational programs in local high schools and in the promotion of the participation of underrepresented minority (URM)  students. 

 


Last Modified: 07/17/2016
Modified by: Hang H Yin
